summary: In this 1958 Court of Appeal decision, the court considered the nature of the estate acquired by D. T. Chandiram when he purchased land from Holomah at a sale under a writ of fi. fa. Holomah had earlier created an equitable mortgage in favor of Barclays Bank by depositing title deeds. Before attachment on September 25, 1954, the deeds were sent to the Bank of the Gold Coast (later Ghana Commercial Bank) to hold on behalf of Barclays Bank. After attachment, the Bank paid off Holomah’s debt to Barclays and received a purported legal mortgage from Holomah on October 27, 1954. The Court held that this mortgage was null and void under Order 43, rule 7, as it was an alienation during attachment without court leave. Thus, the legal estate remained in Holomah, and Chandiram, as purchaser, acquired the full legal estate. The court rejected the appellants’ claim that Chandiram only acquired an equity of redemption, affirming the trial court’s declaration of title, award of damages, mesne profits, and possession to Chandiram. The decision was later reversed by the Privy Council in 1960.
verdict: The appeal was dismissed. The trial court's decision in favor of Chandiram was upheld, granting him declaration of title, recovery of possession, damages for trespass, and mesne profits.
citations: Dadzie v. Kojo and Another (1940) 6 W.A.C.A. 139
Order 43, rule 7, Supreme Court (Civil Procedure) Rules, 1954
Order 43, rule 11, Supreme Court (Civil Procedure) Rules, 1954
rationaleHighlights: A mortgage requires a pre-existing debt; mere custody of title deeds does not create a mortgage.
A legal mortgage executed after attachment is void under Order 43, rule 7.
The purchaser at a fi. fa. sale acquires the legal estate if it was vested in the judgment debtor.
No transfer of mortgage interest occurred without formal assignment from Barclays Bank.
The Ghana Commercial Bank could not claim an equitable mortgage by paying off another bank's debt without intent to assume the security.
The legal estate remained in Holomah at the time of sale, so Chandiram acquired full legal title.
An equity of redemption is the right to reclaim property upon repayment, not a freehold interest.
The trial court correctly rejected the defense that Chandiram bought only an equity of redemption.
